Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Bioinformatics into the Life Sciences - Phase 2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: A partnership of three Nebraska institutions--the University of Nebraska at Omaha, the University of Nebraska at Kearney and Nebraska Wesleyan University--are developing and implementing bioinformatics-focused laboratory exercises across the life sciences curriculum. The project builds on previous NSF-funded work to add bioinformatics content to lecture courses. The lecture material, the student laboratory modules and the tools developed to help students use bioinformatics databases are all freely available at a website maintained and updated by the PIs (http://ccli.ist.unomaha.edu). The intellectual merit of this project resides in its potential to enable students at all levels to understand the potential of bioinformatics as a discipline and in the interesting subject matter of the problems posed and modules produced. These latter include such subjects as analysis of Neanderthal gene sequences and using protein analysis to unravel the history of life on earth. Broader impacts lie in the synergism created by adding inquiry-based laboratories to previously developed lecture content in order to provide a foundation of bioinformatics education at all levels in the life sciences and a dissemination plan that includes partnering with publishers to include versions of the modules as supplementary materials in their textbooks.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers at three diverse universities in Nebraska --the University of Nebraska at Omaha, the University of Nebraska at Kearney, and Nebraska Wesleyan University--permanently modified the life sciences curricula at these institutions by developing and implementing bioinformatics-focused laboratory exercises. (Bioinformatics is a new interdisciplinary field that is concerned with the development and application of algorithms that analyze biological data to investigate the structure and function of biological polymers and their relationships to living systems.) The project built on previous NSF-funded work to add bioinformatics content to lecture courses. Over the course of the project, sixteen laboratory modules were developed, and over 5,250 students were affected by the intervention. The lecture materials, student laboratory modules, and the tools developed to help students use bioinformatics are all freely available at a website maintained by the PIs. The intellectual merit of this project lies in how it enabled undergraduate students at all levels to understand the potential of bioinformatics as a discipline and in the interesting subject matter of the problems posed and modules produced. These latter include such topics as analysis of ancient DNA and using protein sequences to unravel the history of life on earth. Broader impacts lie in the synergism created by adding inquiry-based laboratories to previously developed lecture content to provide a foundation of bioinformatics education at all levels in the life sciences and a dissemination plan that included making the materials available on the project website, presenting the modules at conferences, and publishing them in journals.


Last Modified: 10/29/2016
Modified by: Mark A Pauley

Over the course of the project, sixteen laboratory modules were developed, and over 5,250 students were affected by the intervention. The intellectual merit of this project lies in how it enabled undergraduate students at all levels to understand the potential of bioinformatics as a discipline and in the interesting subject matter of the problems posed and modules produced. Broader impacts lie in the synergism created by adding inquiry-based laboratories to previously developed lecture content to provide a foundation of bioinformatics education at all levels in the life sciences and a dissemination plan that included making the materials available on the project website, presenting the modules at conferences, and publishing them in journals.
